text: What does a solid white line between lanes indicate?
choices: Lane changes are discouraged but permitted if safe
explanation: Solid white lines discourage lane changes but do not legally prohibit them. Drivers should avoid crossing solid white lines unless necessary for safety.

text: What does a dashed white line between lanes mean?
explanation: Dashed white lines separate lanes of traffic moving in the same direction and indicate that lane changes are permitted when safe to do so.

text: What does a double solid yellow line indicate?
choices: Passing is prohibited in both directions
explanation: Double solid yellow lines mark a no-passing zone for traffic traveling in both directions. Crossing these lines to pass is illegal and dangerous.

text: What is the primary difference between yellow and white pavement lines?
choices: Yellow separates opposing traffic, white separates same-direction traffic
Yellow means caution, white means proceed
Yellow is for highways, white is for city streets
Yellow marks parking areas, white marks driving lanes
explanation: Yellow lines separate traffic flowing in opposite directions, while white lines separate lanes of traffic moving in the same direction. This color coding helps drivers understand traffic flow patterns.

text: When you see a single dashed yellow line, what does it indicate?
explanation: A single dashed yellow line indicates that passing is permitted in both directions when it is safe to do so and you can see far enough ahead.

text: What does it mean when there is a double yellow line with one solid and one dashed line?
choices: You can pass only if the dashed line is on your side
You can pass from either direction
No one can pass from either direction
explanation: With a solid/dashed combination, passing is allowed only from the side with the dashed line. If the solid line is on your side, you cannot pass.

text: What does a white edge line on the right side of the road mark?
explanation: White edge lines mark the right boundary of the roadway where the driving surface ends. They help drivers maintain proper lane position, especially at night or in poor weather.

text: If you are driving and the solid yellow line is on your side with a dashed yellow line on the opposite side, what should you do?
choices: Do not pass, passing is only allowed for opposing traffic
Pass when safe to do so
Pass only if no traffic is visible
Slow down and prepare to stop
explanation: When the solid yellow line is on your side, you are prohibited from passing. Only vehicles on the side with the dashed line may pass when safe.

text: What do wider and more frequently spaced dashes in a white line indicate?
choices: An exit or entrance lane is approaching
explanation: Wider, more frequent dashes indicate a lane transition area where vehicles will be entering or exiting the roadway. This gives drivers advance warning to prepare for merging traffic.

text: What does a yellow edge line on the left side of a divided highway indicate?
choices: The left edge of traffic traveling in your direction
explanation: On divided highways, a yellow line on the left marks the left edge of your traffic lanes, separating your direction from the opposing traffic lanes or median.

text: When approaching a solid white line at an intersection, what does it indicate?
choices: You should not change lanes within the intersection
explanation: Solid white lines at intersections discourage lane changes through the intersection, helping maintain orderly traffic flow and reducing collision risks.

text: Are you legally required to stop at a solid white line?
choices: No, it only discourages lane changes
Yes, all solid white lines require stopping
Only if a police officer is present
explanation: Solid white lines discourage but do not legally prohibit lane changes. You should only cross them when necessary and safe to do so.

text: What is the purpose of longer dashed white lines with shorter gaps?
choices: To mark a lane drop or merge area requiring extra caution
explanation: Extended dashes with reduced gaps signal transition zones where lanes are ending or merging, alerting drivers to use extra caution and prepare for lane changes.

text: What does a double solid white line between lanes indicate?
choices: Crossing is prohibited except in emergencies
Lanes are for same direction but different vehicle types
Parking is permitted on both sides
explanation: Double solid white lines indicate a barrier between lanes that should not be crossed except in emergency situations. These often separate HOV lanes or mark restricted zones.

text: Why are yellow lines used instead of white on undivided two-way roads?
choices: To warn drivers that oncoming traffic is in the adjacent lane
explanation: Yellow lines clearly identify that traffic on the other side is traveling in the opposite direction, providing an important visual warning about oncoming vehicles.

text: When can you legally cross a double solid yellow line?
choices: When turning left into or out of a driveway or side street
When visibility is clear for at least 500 feet
explanation: While you cannot pass across double solid yellow lines, you may cross them to turn left into or out of driveways, alleys, or side streets when it is safe to do so.

text: What do broken white lines that become solid white lines indicate?
choices: Lane changes should end, an intersection or restricted area is ahead
Emergency vehicles only beyond this point
explanation: The transition from broken to solid white lines warns drivers to complete lane changes before reaching an area where lane changes are discouraged, such as approaching intersections.

text: What does it mean when yellow lines are painted on both sides of your lane?
choices: You are in a center turn lane shared by traffic from both directions
You are in a restricted zone
You are driving the wrong way
You are in a passing zone
explanation: Yellow lines on both sides indicate a two-way left turn lane that is shared by traffic from both directions for making left turns only.

text: Which color line separates traffic moving in opposite directions?
explanation: Yellow lines are always used to separate traffic flowing in opposite directions, providing a clear visual warning of oncoming traffic.

text: If you see solid yellow lines transitioning to dashed yellow lines, what is changing?
choices: You are entering a zone where passing is now permitted
explanation: The transition from solid to dashed yellow lines indicates the end of a no-passing zone and the beginning of an area where passing is allowed when safe.

text: What does a wide white edge line indicate?
choices: The edge of the roadway, often used where extra visibility is needed
explanation: Wider white edge lines provide enhanced visibility of the roadway edge, especially useful in areas with limited lighting, curves, or poor weather conditions.

text: What is the significance of seeing a dashed yellow line that becomes solid yellow?
choices: A no-passing zone is beginning, complete passes before reaching the solid line
explanation: This transition warns drivers that a no-passing zone is ahead. Any passing maneuver must be completed before reaching the solid yellow line.

text: On a three-lane road with dashed yellow on both sides of the center lane, who can use the center lane?
choices: Traffic from both directions for left turns only
Only traffic traveling north or east
explanation: This describes a two-way left turn lane where drivers from both directions can enter briefly to make left turns. It is not for passing or through traffic.

text: What should you do when approaching an area where solid white lines separate multiple lanes in the same direction?
choices: Avoid changing lanes and stay in your current lane
Change lanes quickly before the lines become double
explanation: Solid white lines indicate that lane changes are discouraged in that area. Drivers should remain in their lane to maintain traffic flow and safety.

text: Under what condition might you see both yellow and white lines together in the same lane area?
choices: At a transition from one-way to two-way traffic flow
explanation: Yellow and white lines together typically mark transitions between one-way streets (white lines) and two-way roads (yellow center line), helping drivers understand changing traffic patterns.

text: What does a left turn arrow painted on the pavement indicate?
explanation: A left turn arrow on the pavement indicates a mandatory turn lane. Vehicles in this lane must turn left at the intersection.

text: What does a straight arrow painted on the pavement mean?
explanation: A straight arrow indicates that vehicles in this lane must proceed straight through the intersection and are not permitted to turn.

text: What does the word 'ONLY' painted on the pavement indicate?
choices: The lane is restricted to the designated direction or purpose shown
Only one car allowed at a time
explanation: ONLY emphasizes that the lane is exclusively designated for a specific use, such as turning or a particular vehicle type, and cannot be used for other purposes.

text: What do zebra-striped white markings on the pavement indicate?
explanation: Zebra-stripe markings designate pedestrian crosswalks. Drivers must yield to pedestrians within these marked crossing areas.

text: What does a thick white line across the lane at an intersection indicate?
choices: The stopping point for traffic signals or stop signs
explanation: A stop line marks where vehicles must stop when required by a traffic signal, stop sign, or to yield to pedestrians. Vehicles should not enter the intersection beyond this line.

text: What do white triangles pointing toward your vehicle indicate?
choices: A yield line where you must give right-of-way
explanation: Yield line triangles point toward approaching traffic to indicate where drivers must yield right-of-way to other vehicles or pedestrians. This is common at roundabouts and yield intersections.

text: What does a right turn arrow painted on the pavement mean?
explanation: A right turn arrow designates a mandatory right turn lane. Vehicles positioned in this lane must turn right and cannot proceed straight.

text: What does a combined left and straight arrow on the pavement indicate?
choices: You may either turn left or continue straight from this lane
You must choose left or straight before entering the lane
Left turns have priority over straight traffic
explanation: A combined arrow indicates an optional lane where drivers may either turn or proceed straight. Both movements are permitted from this lane.

text: When you see the word 'STOP' painted on the pavement, what does it indicate?
choices: A stop line position even if the painted line is worn away
explanation: STOP painted on the pavement reinforces the stop requirement and shows where to stop, especially useful when stop lines have faded or in areas where the sign may be less visible.

text: What is the purpose of crosswalk markings at an intersection?
choices: To designate the safe path for pedestrians crossing the street
To indicate where vehicles should stop
explanation: Crosswalk markings guide pedestrians across the street safely and alert drivers to areas where they must yield to foot traffic.

text: If you see arrows and the word 'ONLY' together on the pavement, what does this combination mean?
choices: The lane is exclusively for the movement shown by the arrow
Only one vehicle at a time
Passing is permitted only in this lane
explanation: The combination of an arrow with ONLY creates a mandatory lane designation, meaning vehicles in that lane must follow the arrow's direction exclusively.

text: What should you do when you see a stop line at an intersection?
choices: Stop with your front bumper at or before the line
Stop with your rear bumper at the line
Slow down but you don't need to stop
Stop only if pedestrians are present
explanation: Vehicles must stop at or before the stop line, ensuring the entire vehicle is behind the line. This provides safe clearance for cross traffic and pedestrians.

text: What do school zone pavement markings typically indicate?
choices: Reduced speed limits and increased pedestrian activity ahead
explanation: School zone pavement markings warn drivers to reduce speed and watch carefully for children and crossing guards. These areas require heightened awareness.

text: Why might you see a stop line positioned well back from the intersection?
choices: To provide sight distance for turning vehicles or large truck clearance
To mark a pedestrian waiting area
Because the marking was placed incorrectly
explanation: Stop lines are sometimes set back to improve sight lines at difficult intersections or to provide adequate turning radius for large vehicles like trucks and buses.

text: What does 'NO PASSING ZONE' painted on the pavement mean?
choices: Passing is prohibited in this area due to limited visibility or hazards
You must drive in single file
explanation: NO PASSING ZONE pavement text reinforces that passing maneuvers are prohibited, typically due to limited sight distance, curves, or hills.

text: What does a combined right and straight arrow mean?
choices: You may turn right or continue straight from this lane
You must turn right, but straight traffic may pass on the left
Right turns only during certain hours
explanation: A combined right-straight arrow indicates a shared lane where both right turns and through movements are permitted, giving drivers flexibility in their direction.

text: If there is no marked crosswalk at an intersection, where should pedestrians cross?
choices: At the extension of the sidewalk across the intersection
explanation: Even without painted markings, an unmarked crosswalk exists at intersections where sidewalks extend. Pedestrians have the right-of-way, and drivers must yield.

text: What color are most pavement arrows and word markings?
explanation: Pavement arrows and word markings are typically white because they provide lane-use guidance for traffic moving in the same direction, consistent with white line usage.

text: What should you do if you realize you are in a turn-only lane but need to go straight?
choices: Complete the turn and find a safe way to return to your route
Stop and back up to change lanes
Turn on hazard lights and stop
explanation: Once in a mandatory turn lane, you must complete the turn as indicated. Attempting to go straight or change lanes at the last moment creates dangerous situations.

text: Why are some crosswalks marked with two parallel lines while others use zebra stripes?
choices: Both are valid; zebra stripes provide higher visibility in high-traffic areas
Zebra stripes are only for school zones
Parallel lines mean yield, zebra means stop
Different cities use different standards randomly
explanation: Both marking styles are legal crosswalks. Zebra stripes are often used in high-traffic or high-risk areas because they provide better visibility and draw more attention from drivers.

text: What is the primary purpose of white pavement markings?
choices: To separate lanes of traffic moving in the same direction
explanation: White markings are used to organize and separate traffic moving in the same direction, helping drivers stay in proper lanes and make safe lane changes.

text: What is the primary purpose of yellow pavement markings?
choices: To separate traffic moving in opposite directions
explanation: Yellow markings separate traffic flows in opposite directions, warning drivers that vehicles on the other side of the line are approaching them head-on.

text: What does a red curb indicate?
choices: No stopping or parking at any time
explanation: Red curbs designate no-stopping zones. Vehicles cannot stop, stand, or park in these areas, which are often near fire hydrants or emergency access points.

text: What does a blue curb indicate?
choices: Parking reserved for disabled persons with proper permits
explanation: Blue curbs mark disabled parking spaces. Only vehicles displaying valid disabled parking permits or license plates may park in these designated areas.

text: What does a white curb typically indicate?
choices: Passenger loading and unloading only for a limited time
explanation: White curbs designate passenger loading zones where vehicles can stop briefly to pick up or drop off passengers but cannot park for extended periods.

text: What does a yellow curb indicate?
choices: Loading zone or no parking during posted hours
explanation: Yellow curbs typically mark commercial loading zones where parking is prohibited but brief stops for loading/unloading are permitted during specified times.

text: What does a green curb indicate?
explanation: Green curbs designate short-term parking areas with time limits, typically 15-30 minutes. These allow for brief stops while preventing all-day parking.

text: Can you stop at a red curb to let a passenger out?
choices: No, red curbs prohibit all stopping
Yes, if you stay in the vehicle
explanation: Red curbs mean absolutely no stopping at any time. This includes dropping off passengers, as these areas must remain clear for emergency access or fire safety.

text: Why do yellow and white lines have different meanings?
choices: To help drivers quickly identify whether adjacent traffic is traveling the same or opposite direction
Yellow is older, white is newer
Different colors for different speed limits
To distinguish urban from rural roads
explanation: The color-coding system provides instant visual information about traffic flow direction, which is critical for safety when deciding whether passing or lane changes are safe.

text: What does colored pavement in a bike lane indicate?
choices: Enhanced visibility of the bike lane, especially at conflict points
explanation: Colored pavement in bike lanes increases visibility at intersections, driveways, or other locations where vehicle-bicycle conflicts are more likely to occur.

text: What is the difference between a white curb and a blue curb?
choices: White is for passenger loading, blue is for disabled parking only
White is daytime only, blue is 24-hours
White is free, blue requires payment
explanation: White curbs allow brief stops for passenger loading by any vehicle, while blue curbs are exclusively reserved for vehicles with disabled parking credentials.

text: When is parking at a green curb typically allowed?
choices: For the limited time posted on nearby signs
explanation: Green curbs indicate time-limited parking. Drivers must check posted signs for specific time limits and any applicable hours of enforcement.

text: What does it mean when the pavement in a bike lane is painted green?
choices: It highlights conflict zones where drivers must be especially cautious of bicyclists
Only green bikes can use this lane
explanation: Green pavement within bike lanes marks areas of potential conflict between bicycles and turning vehicles, alerting both to exercise extra caution.

text: Are you required to park within white painted parking space lines?
choices: Yes, to ensure adequate space for other vehicles and safe access
Only if a parking attendant is present
explanation: White parking space lines must be observed to ensure orderly parking, accessibility, and adequate space for all vehicles and pedestrians.

text: What legal difference exists between a solid yellow curb and a yellow curb with specific time restrictions posted?
choices: Solid yellow may have restrictions that apply 24/7, while posted times indicate when restrictions are active
No difference, both mean the same thing
Solid yellow is more restrictive than posted times
Posted times override the yellow curb meaning entirely
explanation: Yellow curbs must be evaluated based on posted signage. Without time-specific signs, restrictions may apply at all times. Posted signs specify exactly when loading is permitted or prohibited.

text: What does a bicycle symbol painted on the pavement with a solid white line indicate?
choices: A designated bike lane that vehicles should not enter
explanation: A bicycle symbol with a solid white line marks a dedicated bike lane. Motor vehicles should not drive or park in these lanes except when necessary to turn.

text: What does a white diamond symbol painted on the pavement indicate?
choices: A high-occupancy vehicle (HOV) or carpool lane
explanation: Diamond symbols mark HOV lanes reserved for vehicles with multiple occupants. Check posted signs for specific occupancy requirements and hours of operation.

text: What does a bicycle symbol with chevron markings (sharrow) indicate?
choices: A shared lane where bicycles and vehicles both have right to use the full lane
Bicycles must stay to the right
explanation: Sharrows indicate shared lane usage where bicycles and motor vehicles share the travel lane. They remind drivers that cyclists have the right to use the full lane.

text: What do the pavement markings for a center two-way left turn lane look like?
choices: Yellow lines on both sides with breaks and arrows pointing in both directions
Solid white lines on both sides
Single dashed yellow line in the center
explanation: Center turn lanes have distinctive yellow lines on both sides with arrows showing that traffic from both directions uses this lane exclusively for left turns, not through travel.

text: What does an X with the letters RR painted on the pavement indicate?
explanation: The RR with an X marking warns drivers that railroad tracks cross the road ahead. Drivers should slow down and look for trains before crossing.

text: How should you use a center two-way left turn lane?
choices: Enter only to prepare for a left turn, not for passing or through travel
Use it to pass slow-moving vehicles
Use it to merge into traffic
Use it as a continuous travel lane
explanation: Center turn lanes are exclusively for preparing to turn left. Drivers should enter the lane close to their turning point and not use it for passing or extended travel.

text: What does a handicapped parking symbol painted on the pavement indicate?
choices: Parking space reserved for vehicles displaying disabled parking credentials
explanation: The wheelchair symbol marks parking spaces legally reserved for people with disabilities who display valid disabled parking permits or license plates.

text: Can you drive in a bike lane to prepare for a right turn?
choices: Yes, you should merge into the bike lane within 200 feet of the turn when safe
No, never enter a bike lane
Yes, at any distance from the turn
Only if no bicycles are visible
explanation: Drivers should merge into the bike lane before turning right to avoid cutting off cyclists. Check for bicyclists, signal, and merge safely within 200 feet of the intersection.

text: What is the purpose of a sharrow versus a dedicated bike lane?
choices: Sharrows indicate shared use of the lane, while bike lanes provide exclusive space for bicycles
Sharrows are for faster cyclists only
They mean exactly the same thing
Sharrows are temporary, bike lanes are permanent
explanation: Sharrows are used where space is insufficient for a separate bike lane, reminding drivers that cyclists have equal rights to the lane. Bike lanes provide dedicated space separated by lines.

text: What should you do when approaching an HOV lane marked with diamonds?
choices: Check posted signs for occupancy requirements and hours before entering
Enter if your vehicle has two or more axles
These lanes are for emergency vehicles only
explanation: HOV lanes have varying requirements for number of occupants and restricted hours. Always check posted signage before entering to ensure compliance with current regulations.
